name: WordPress
notes: Silktide provides a built-in integration for deep-linking (Edit button).

name: Drupal (7–11)
notes: Silktide supports Drupal 7–11 via built-in integration guides.

name: Adobe Experience Manager (AEM)
notes: Built-in AEM integration.

name: Umbraco
notes: Built-in Umbraco integration.

name: Progress Sitefinity
notes: Built-in Sitefinity integration.

name: Craft CMS
notes: Built-in Craft CMS integration (guide references Craft CMS 3).

name: Terminalfour
notes: Built-in Terminalfour integration.

name: Jadu
notes: Built-in Jadu integration.

name: Cascade CMS (Hannon Hill)
notes: Cascade editor URLs are asset-ID based; public URLs typically do not include the internal asset ID, so Silktide cannot reliably derive editor links via URL transform. Output a per-page silktide-cms meta tag containing the correct editorUrl.

name: TYPO3
notes: TYPO3 backend deep links include internal page uid and often a security token/route; public URL alone isn’t enough. Use meta tag built from page uid + backend route.

name: Joomla
notes: Use a per-page silktide-cms meta tag to provide the exact editor URL for each page.

name: Shopify
notes: Admin URLs are ID-based; in Liquid you can access object.id for products/pages/blog posts and build the editorUrl meta tag.

name: Adobe Commerce (Magento)
notes: Admin edit screens use entity IDs and often require an authenticated session; do not include tokens in editor URLs. Use meta tag with non-tokenized edit URL.

name: BigCommerce
notes: Admin edit screens are ID-based. Use storefront templates to emit meta tag if you can access product/page IDs; otherwise rely on URL transform is not recommended.

name: Webflow
notes: Webflow editing URLs are not reliably derivable from public URLs without internal IDs; deep linking to a specific page is typically not feasible.

name: Wix
notes: Deep linking to edit a specific page is generally not feasible; Wix uses editor/session context. Consider linking to the site dashboard only, or skip edit links.

name: Squarespace
notes: Page-specific edit deep links are generally not feasible; editor URLs are not stable per page. Consider linking to the site dashboard only, or skip edit links.

name: HubSpot CMS
notes: HubSpot editor URLs include portal ID and content ID. If your templates can access these IDs, emit meta tag; otherwise edit deep links may be limited.

name: Sitecore
notes: Many Sitecore sites support Experience Editor via predictable URL changes (e.g., query params like sc_mode=edit and/or host swap). If your setup requires item IDs, use the meta tag strategy.

name: Optimizely CMS
notes: Optimizely supports on-page editing; some implementations use epieditmode=True on specific CMS URLs (often includes internal IDs). Treat as meta tag by default, but URL transform may work if your preview URLs are deterministic.

name: Kentico Xperience
notes: Often requires internal identifiers (NodeID/DocumentID). If on-site editing is enabled, some setups allow an edit-mode URL derived from the public path (e.g., /cmsctx/... + editmode=1). Otherwise use meta tag built from CMS IDs.

name: SharePoint Online
notes: Some SharePoint Online pages can be opened in edit mode via predictable URL parameters (varies by tenant/page type). If not, fall back to meta tag with internal IDs or link to the site’s Pages/Library UI.

name: Liferay DXP
notes: Liferay pages can be opened in edit mode by adding p_l_mode=edit to the page URL (requires permissions).

name: Magnolia
notes: Typically edited via AdminCentral/Pages app and internal node paths/UUIDs; no universal 1:1 URL transform from public URL. Use meta tag built from Magnolia page node info.

name: Contentful
notes: Headless: frontend can emit meta tag with the entry ID and a preconfigured space/environment.

name: Sanity
notes: Headless: emit meta tag with document ID and studio URL (often uses intents).

name: Prismic
notes: Headless: emit meta tag with document ID/UID and repository name.

name: Storyblok
notes: Headless: emit meta tag with story ID and space ID, pointing into the Visual Editor.

name: Strapi
notes: Emit meta tag with collection type + entry ID and Strapi admin URL.

name: Contentstack
notes: Use a per-page silktide-cms meta tag to provide the exact editor URL for each page.

name: Ghost
notes: Ghost supports a front-end “/edit” shortcut: append /edit to the public post/page URL to redirect to the editor (login required).

name: WooCommerce
notes: Silktide provides a built-in integration for deep-linking (Edit button).

name: PrestaShop
notes: Admin edit URLs typically require internal IDs (product/category/CMS page).

name: Shopware
notes: Admin edit URLs usually include entity IDs; public slugs aren’t enough.

name: Plone
notes: Plone supports action URLs like /edit on the same content URL, so editorUrl can be derived from the public URL.

name: django CMS
notes: Many setups allow entering edit mode by appending ?edit to the current page URL (logged-in editors).

name: MODX
notes: Manager edit URLs are resource-ID based; public slugs don’t reliably include IDs.

name: Silverstripe CMS
notes: Admin edit routes are ID-based (pages/records).

name: Concrete CMS (Concrete5)
notes: Some sites use on-page editing (same URL for editors), others route through dashboard pages with cID. If you can reliably derive edit mode from public URL, use transform; otherwise meta tag with page ID.

name: ProcessWire
notes: Admin edit URLs require the page ID; public URL is path-based.

name: October CMS
notes: Back-end editing is record-ID based and front-end URLs are developer-defined.

name: Statamic
notes: Entry editing URLs in the Control Panel depend on collection/blueprint structure. If your public paths map cleanly to CP entry routes, use transform; otherwise generate editorUrl in meta tag from entry identifiers.

name: Directus
notes: Editor UI is collection + item-ID based; public URLs are app-specific.

name: DatoCMS
notes: Editor URLs are model/item-ID based and not derivable from public slugs.

name: Kontent.ai
notes: Editor URLs use internal item IDs/codenames; public URL mapping is custom.

name: Hygraph (GraphCMS)
notes: Editor is model + entry-ID based; public URLs are app-defined.

name: Builder.io
notes: Editing happens inside Builder with content IDs/spaces; public URLs are typically mapped via model/URL fields.

name: Brightspot
notes: Authoring is ID-based and implementation-specific; public URLs don’t reliably encode item IDs.

name: Crownpeak
notes: Authoring UI uses internal asset IDs; public URL mapping varies.

name: Tridion Sites (SDL Tridion)
notes: Editing is ID-based (items/components/pages) and not derivable from public URLs.

name: HCL Digital Experience (DX)
notes: Some deployments support in-context editing on the live URL; others require control panel routes with internal IDs. If edit mode can be enabled via URL parameters, use transform; otherwise generate editorUrl via meta tag using internal IDs.
